The BPE algorithm starts with a vocabulary of all the words in the training set. Then, it creates a table of all the sequences of characters in the training set, sorted by frequency. The most frequent sequence of characters is added to the vocabulary, and its occurrences in the training set are replaced with a special token representing the sequence. This process is repeated until the desired vocabulary size is reached. BPE has the advantage of being able to handle out-of-vocabulary words, as it can split unknown words into known subwords.

During tokenization, special tokens are used to mark the beginning and end of a sentence, as well as unknown tokens. These tokens are added to the vocabulary and assigned unique integer IDs. The integer IDs of the tokens are then used as input to the model, and the model's output is converted back into text using a decoding algorithm.

 Problems

One problem with tokenization is that English-optimized tokenizers tend to tokenize words from other languages into subwords, resulting in less efficient processing. For example, the Shan language from Myanmar contains many long words that are difficult to tokenize into subwords, as most subwords would be very rare. GPT-2 tokenizer can use up to 15 times more tokens per word on average when processing Shan compared to English. A similar problem occurs with Portuguese and German, among other languages.

 Dataset cleaning

A large language model's training data should be free of low-quality data, duplicates, and toxic content. Low-quality data can harm the model's performance, while duplicates can waste computational resources, and toxic content can harm people's feelings or spread harmful ideas. One way to clean a dataset is to use a trained large language model to identify and remove low-quality data, duplicates, and toxic content. The model can generate a score or a label for each data point, indicating its quality, uniqueness, and toxicity. Data points with low scores or toxic labels can be removed from the dataset.

 Synthetic data

The largest language models are trained on datasets that consist of tens of thousands of gigabytes of text. This requires a lot of data collection, which can be difficult and expensive. One way to obtain more data is to generate synthetic data using a smaller language model. The smaller language model can generate text that is similar to the text in the original dataset, but does not necessarily have to be identical. This synthetic data can be used to augment the original dataset, making it larger and more diverse.

Microsoft's Phi series of language models uses synthetic data to train the models. The synthetic data is generated by a smaller language model that is trained on the original dataset. The synthetic data is then mixed with the original dataset and used to train a larger language model.

 Training and architecture

Large language models are usually trained using the transformer architecture, a neural network architecture that was introduced in the paper "Attention Is All You Need" by Vaswani et al. in 2017. The transformer architecture consists of multiple layers of attention mechanisms, which allow the model to focus on different parts of the input sequence when generating each part of the output sequence. The attention mechanisms are combined with feed-forward neural networks, which are used to transform the output of the attention mechanisms.

The transformer architecture is used in large language models because it allows the model to attend to different parts of the input sequence when generating each part of the output sequence. This allows the model to capture long-range dependencies in the input sequence, which are important for understanding the meaning of a sentence or a paragraph. The transformer architecture is also computationally efficient, which allows the model to be trained on large datasets using GPUs.

 Reinforcement learning from human feedback

Large language models can be fine-tuned using reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) to maximize a reward model's estimate of a prompt and response. This can be used to encourage or discourage certain behaviors, such as being more polite or less likely to tell jokes.

 Instruction tuning

Instruction tuning is a technique for fine-tuning a large language model on a specific task. Instead of directly rewarding or penalizing the model for producing certain words, as in direct reward feedback, the model is rewarded or penalized for its ability to produce a response given a specific instruction and input. This can be useful for tasks where the desired output format or content is specified in the instruction.

One approach to instruction tuning is self-instruct, which generates new training data by having the model solve in-context examples. The in-context examples are generated by giving the model a few demonstrations of the task, and asking the model to solve a few practice problems. The solutions to the practice problems are then used as instructions for the model.

 Mixture of experts

The mixture of experts (MoE) is a technique for training a large language model that uses multiple smaller models, called experts, instead of a single large model. Each expert is responsible for a subset of the model's parameters, and only a subset of the experts are active at any given time. This allows the model to be more efficient in terms of memory and computation, as only the active experts need to be loaded into memory and computed.

MoE has been shown to be effective for large language models, as it allows the model to be more expressive without requiring a large increase in the number of parameters. This can lead to improved performance on a variety of tasks.

 Infrastructure

Training large language models requires a lot of computational resources, including powerful GPUs and TPUs, large amounts of RAM, and fast network connectivity. The training process can take weeks or even months, and require terabytes of storage space for the model checkpoints and training logs.

Training large language models also requires a lot of energy, which can be a significant cost factor. The energy consumption of training a large language model can be comparable to the lifetime energy consumption of an average person. To reduce the carbon footprint of training large language models, researchers are exploring techniques such as mixed precision training, which uses lower-precision data types to reduce memory bandwidth and energy consumption.

 Training cost

The cost of training a large language model depends on several factors, including the size of the model, the size of the dataset, the duration of the training, and the cost of the hardware and cloud services used for training. The cost of training a large language model can be quite high, and is usually measured in dollars or equivalent cryptocurrencies.

The cost of training a large language model can be reduced by using techniques such as knowledge distillation, where a smaller model is trained to imitate the behavior of a larger model, or by using transfer learning, where a pre-trained model is fine-tuned on a smaller dataset.

The cost of training a large language model can also be reduced by using cheaper hardware, such as consumer-grade GPUs or TPUs, instead of high-end server-grade hardware. However, this may require more time and effort to set up and manage the hardware.

 Tool use

While large language models are very powerful, they still have limitations. They cannot solve complex mathematical problems or perform tasks that require a deep understanding of the world, such as scientific discovery or engineering. Instead, they are best used as a tool to augment human creativity and productivity.

One way to use a large language model as a tool is to integrate it into a larger system that can provide context and structure to the inputs and outputs. For example, a system for generating code from natural language descriptions could use a large language model to generate the initial code, and then use a compiler or interpreter to check the code for correctness. The system could also use a version control system to keep track of changes to the code over time.

Another way to use a large language model as a tool is to combine it with other machine learning models. For example, a computer vision model could be used to extract images from a video, and then a large language model could be used to generate captions for the images. The captions could then be used to improve the performance of the computer vision model.

 Large language models can also be used to generate synthetic data, which can be used to train other machine learning models. For example, a large language model could be used to generate synthetic medical records, which could be used to train a machine learning model to diagnose diseases.

However, there are also potential risks associated with using large language models as a tool. For example, if the model is not carefully controlled, it could generate biased or harmful content. Therefore, it is important to have robust safety and control mechanisms in place when using large language models.

The ReAct pattern, proposed by Peter Clark, adds a short-term memory to the LLM and allows it to output a plan of action before generating text. The plan of action is executed, and the results are stored in the short-term memory. The Reflexion method can be used to improve the performance of LLMs on tasks that require reflexion and adaptation.

 Compression

Large language models can be compressed to reduce their size and make them more efficient to train and deploy. There are two main types of compression: pruning and quantization.

Pruning is a technique that removes unnecessary parameters from the model, while quantization is a technique that reduces the precision of the model's parameters. Both techniques can reduce the size of the model by several orders of magnitude, making it easier to deploy on devices with limited memory.

One popular technique for compressing large language models is post-training quantization, which converts the model's parameters from 32-bit floating point numbers to lower-precision formats such as 8-bit integers or 16-bit floating point numbers. This can reduce the model's size by a factor of 4 or 8, respectively, without significant loss in performance. Post-training quantization is simple and efficient, but it requires a large amount of training data to ensure that the lower-precision representation captures the full range of values in the original model.

Another popular technique for compressing large language models is knowledge distillation, which involves training a smaller model to mimic the behavior of a larger model. The smaller model can then be used in place of the larger model, providing similar performance at a much lower cost. Knowledge distillation requires careful tuning of the training process to ensure that the smaller model learns the essential features of the larger model, and it may not be suitable for all applications.

 Properties

Large language models are very powerful, but they are not perfect. They have several known limitations and challenges that researchers are working to overcome.

One limitation of large language models is that they are prone to hallucination, which means that they may generate output that is factually incorrect or nonsensical. This can happen because the models are trained on large amounts of text data, which may contain errors or outdated information. To mitigate this problem, researchers are developing techniques such as contrastive learning and reward modeling, which encourage the models to generate more accurate and reliable output.

Another challenge of large language models is that they can be difficult to interpret. Because the models use complex neural networks with many layers and parameters, it can be difficult to understand how they arrive at a particular output. This lack of interpretability can make it difficult to trust the models or to debug them when they produce errors. To address this problem, researchers are developing techniques such as attention visualization and layer-wise relevance propagation, which can help to shed light on the inner workings of the models.

Despite these challenges, large language models have shown remarkable performance on a variety of tasks, and they hold great promise for the future of natural language processing. As researchers continue to improve the models and address their limitations, we can expect to see even more impressive applications of LLMs in the years to come.

Explanations

LLMs are considered black boxes, as it is difficult to understand how they arrived at a particular output. There are several techniques for explaining LLMs, including attention visualization, layer-wise relevance propagation, and counterfactual explanations.

Attention visualization is a technique that highlights which parts of the input sequence are most relevant to a particular output token. This can help to shed light on the model's thought process and provide insight into how the model is arriving at a particular output. However, attention visualization can be difficult to interpret, and it is not always clear what the model is actually attending to.

Layer-wise relevance propagation is a technique that computes a measure of relevance for each input token by backpropagating from the output layer to the input layer. This can help to highlight which parts of the input sequence are most important for a particular output, and can provide insight into the model's decision-making process. However, layer-wise relevance propagation can be sensitive to the choice of activation function, and it may not always produce intuitive or interpretable results.

Counterfactual explanations are explanations that describe how the output of the model would change if the input were modified in some way. For example, a counterfactual explanation for a model's classification of an image as a "cat" might be that if the image were replaced with an image of a "dog", the model would classify it as a "dog" instead. Counterfactual explanations can be useful for understanding the robustness of the model and for identifying potential sources of error. However, they can be difficult to compute and interpret, especially for large models.

 Evaluation

The performance of a language model can be evaluated using a variety of metrics, such as perplexity, BLEU, ROUGE, and accuracy. Perplexity is a measure of how well a probability distribution or probability model predicts a sample. In the context of language models, perplexity is used to evaluate how well the model is able to predict the next word in a sentence. The lower the perplexity, the better the model is at predicting the next word.

BLEU (Bilingual Evaluation Understudy) is a metric for evaluating the quality of machine translation. It compares the similarity between the machine-translated sentence and a set of reference translations. The BLEU score is a measure of the overlap between n-grams of the candidate translation and the n-grams of the reference translation.

ROUGE (Recall-Oriented Understudy for Gisting Evaluation) is a metric for evaluating the quality of automatic summarization. It compares the similarity between the automatic summary and a set of reference summaries. The ROUGE score is a measure of the overlap between n-grams of the automatic summary and the n-grams of the reference summary.

Accuracy is a metric for evaluating the performance of a classification model. It is the ratio of correct predictions to the total number of predictions. For example, if a model is able to correctly classify 90 out of 100 samples, its accuracy would be 90%.

Introduction
In natural language processing, a word embedding is a representation of a word. The embedding is used in text analysis. Typically, the representation is a real-valued vector that encodes the meaning of the word in such a way that the words that are closer in the vector space are expected to be similar in meaning. Word embeddings can be obtained using language modeling and feature learning techniques, where words or phrases from the vocabulary are mapped to vectors of real numbers.
Methods to generate this mapping include neural networks, dimensionality reduction on the word co-occurrence matrix, probabilistic models, explainable knowledge base method, and explicit representation in terms of the context in which words appear.
Word and phrase embeddings, when used as the underlying input representation, have been shown to boost the performance in NLP tasks such as syntactic parsing and sentiment analysis.Development and history of the approach
In distributional semantics, a quantitative methodological approach for understanding meaning in observed language, word embeddings or semantic feature space models have been used as a knowledge representation for some time. Such models aim to quantify and categorize semantic similarities between linguistic items based on their distributional properties in large samples of language data.  The underlying idea that "a word is characterized by the company it keeps" was proposed in a 1957 article by John Rupert Firth, but also has roots in the contemporaneous work on search systems and in cognitive psychology.
The notion of a semantic space with lexical items (words or multi-word terms) represented as vectors or embeddings is based on the computational challenges of capturing distributional characteristics and using them for practical application to measure similarity between words, phrases, or entire documents. The first generation of semantic space models is the vector space model for information retrieval. Such vector space models for words and their distributional data implemented in their simplest form results in a very sparse vector space of high dimensionality (cf. curse of dimensionality). Reducing the number of dimensions using linear algebraic methods such as singular value decomposition then led to the introduction of latent semantic analysis in the late 1980s and the random indexing approach for collecting word co-occurrence contexts. In 2000, Bengio et al. provided in a series of papers titled "Neural probabilistic language models" to reduce the high dimensionality of word representations in contexts by "learning a distributed representation for words".
A study published in NeurIPS (NIPS) 2002 introduced the use of both word and document embeddings applying the method of kernel CCA to bilingual (and multi-lingual) corpora, also providing an early example of self-supervised learning of word embeddings.
Word embeddings come in two different styles, one in which words are expressed as vectors of co-occurring words, and another in which words are expressed as vectors of linguistic contexts in which the words occur; these different styles are studied in Lavelli et al., 2004. Roweis and Saul published in Science how to use "locally linear embedding" (LLE) to discover representations of high dimensional data structures. Most new word embedding techniques after about 2005 rely on a neural network architecture instead of more probabilistic and algebraic models, after foundational work done by Yoshua Bengio and colleagues.
The approach has been adopted by many research groups after theoretical advances in 2010 had been made on the quality of vectors and the training speed of the model, as well as after hardware advances allowed for a broader parameter space to be explored profitably. In 2013, a team at Google led by Tomas Mikolov created word2vec, a word embedding toolkit that can train vector space models faster than previous approaches. The word2vec approach has been widely used in experimentation and was instrumental in raising interest for word embeddings as a technology, moving the research strand out of specialised research into broader experimentation and eventually paving the way for practical application.Polysemy and homonymy
Historically, one of the main limitations of static word embeddings or word vector space models is that words with multiple meanings are conflated into a single representation (a single vector in the semantic space). In other words, polysemy and homonymy are not handled properly. For example, in the sentence "The club I tried yesterday was great!", it is not clear if the term club is related to the word sense of a club sandwich, clubhouse, golf club, or any other sense that club might have. The necessity to accommodate multiple meanings per word in different vectors (multi-sense embeddings) is the motivation for several contributions in NLP to split single-sense embeddings into multi-sense ones.
Most approaches that produce multi-sense embeddings can be divided into two main categories for their word sense representation, i.e., unsupervised and knowledge-based. Based on word2vec skip-gram, Multi-Sense Skip-Gram (MSSG) performs word-sense discrimination and embedding simultaneously, improving its training time, while assuming a specific number of senses for each word. In the Non-Parametric Multi-Sense Skip-Gram (NP-MSSG) this number can vary depending on each word. Combining the prior knowledge of lexical databases (e.g., WordNet, ConceptNet, BabelNet), word embeddings and word sense disambiguation, Most Suitable Sense Annotation (MSSA) labels word-senses through an unsupervised and knowledge-based approach, considering a word's context in a pre-defined sliding window. Once the words are disambiguated, they can be used in a standard word embeddings technique, so multi-sense embeddings are produced. MSSA architecture allows the disambiguation and annotation process to be performed recurrently in a self-improving manner.
The use of multi-sense embeddings is known to improve performance in several NLP tasks, such as part-of-speech tagging, semantic relation identification, semantic relatedness, named entity recognition and sentiment analysis.
As of the late 2010s, contextually-meaningful embeddings such as ELMo and BERT have been developed. Unlike static word embeddings, these embeddings are at the token-level, in that each occurrence of a word has its own embedding. These embeddings better reflect the multi-sense nature of words, because occurrences of a word in similar contexts are situated in similar regions of BERT’s embedding space.For biological sequences: BioVectors
Word embeddings for n-grams in biological sequences (e.g. DNA, RNA, and Proteins) for bioinformatics applications have been proposed by Asgari and Mofrad. Named bio-vectors (BioVec) to refer to biological sequences in general with protein-vectors (ProtVec) for proteins (amino-acid sequences) and gene-vectors (GeneVec) for gene sequences, this representation can be widely used in applications of deep learning in proteomics and genomics. The results presented by Asgari and Mofrad suggest that BioVectors can characterize biological sequences in terms of biochemical and biophysical interpretations of the underlying patterns.Game design
Word embeddings with applications in game design have been proposed by Rabii and Cook as a way to discover emergent gameplay using logs of gameplay data. The process requires transcribing actions that occur during a game within a formal language and then using the resulting text to create word embeddings. The results presented by Rabii and Cook suggest that the resulting vectors can capture expert knowledge about games like chess that are not explicitly stated in the game's rules.Sentence embeddings
The idea has been extended to embeddings of entire sentences or even documents, e.g. in the form of the thought vectors concept. In 2015, some researchers suggested "skip-thought vectors" as a means to improve the quality of machine translation. A more recent and popular approach for representing sentences is Sentence-BERT, or SentenceTransformers, which modifies pre-trained BERT with the use of siamese and triplet network structures.Software
Software for training and using word embeddings includes Tomáš Mikolov's Word2vec, Stanford University's GloVe, GN-GloVe, Flair embeddings, AllenNLP's ELMo, BERT, fastText, Gensim, Indra, and Deeplearning4j. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and T-Distributed Stochastic Neighbour Embedding (t-SNE) are both used to reduce the dimensionality of word vector spaces and visualize word embeddings and clusters.Examples of application
For instance, the fastText is also used to calculate word embeddings for text corpora in Sketch Engine that are available online.Ethical implications
Word embeddings may contain the biases and stereotypes contained in the trained dataset, as Bolukbasi et al. points out in the 2016 paper “Man is to Computer Programmer as Woman is to Homemaker? Debiasing Word Embeddings” that a publicly available (and popular) word2vec embedding trained on Google News texts (a commonly used data corpus), which consists of text written by professional journalists, still shows disproportionate word associations reflecting gender and racial biases when extracting word analogies. For example, one of the analogies generated using the aforementioned word embedding is “man is to computer programmer as woman is to homemaker”.
Research done by Jieyu Zhou et al. shows that the applications of these trained word embeddings without careful oversight likely perpetuates existing bias in society, which is introduced through unaltered training data. Furthermore, word embeddings can even amplify these biases .See also

# Word embedding

In natural language processing and computational linguistics, word embedding is a language modeling technique where words or phrases from the vocabulary are mapped to vectors of real numbers. Through the use of word embeddings, the linguistic structure and semantics of text can be modeled. Word embeddings capture the contextual meaning of words by placing semantically similar words in close proximity in the vector space defined by the embedding. Word embeddings are able to capture the semantic meaning of a word by leveraging the distributional hypothesis which states that words that appear in the same contexts are likely to have similar meanings. Common methods for generating word embeddings include neural networks and probabilistic models, where words are mapped to vectors in a continuous vector space and the similarity between words is measured using vector space operations. Word embeddings are used in many natural language processing and text analysis tasks, such as language modeling, machine translation, and sentiment analysis.

 Development and history of the approach

The history of word embedding dates back to the distributional hypothesis in the mid-20th century. The distributional hypothesis states that words occurring in the same contexts tend to have similar meanings. The first method for word embedding was created by J. R. Firth, who stated that "you shall know a word by the company it keeps". In the 1960s, computer scientist James Allen developed the first word embedding model, which was a precursor to modern word embedding models. Allen's model embedded words in a two-dimensional vector space, where the positions of the words were determined by the frequencies of the words in documents. Words that appeared together frequently were placed closer to each other in the vector space.

Due to limitations in computational power and data size, Allen's model and subsequent distributional models were not able to create low-dimensional embeddings. Instead, these models generated high-dimensional embeddings that were too complex to analyze. With the advent of powerful computers and large digitized text, modern word embedding models were created to overcome the limitations of previous models. By 2000, the distributional hypothesis and its associated models had largely fallen out of favor within computational linguistics.

Word embedding models became popular again with the introduction of large pre-trained language models in the early 2010s. Pre-trained language models automatically learn word embeddings during the training of the overall model. The large amount of data and parameters used in pre-trained language models allows them to create high-quality word embeddings that previous distributional models were unable to achieve. Instead of analyzing and fine-tuning the embeddings learned by pre-trained models, some researchers have attempted to create new word embeddings by training simpler models, such as skip-gram, on specific datasets. As pre-trained language models continue to improve, word embeddings created by simpler models have shown minimal improvement in most tasks.

 Polysemy and homonymy

Static word embeddings face issues when dealing with words with multiple meanings (polysemous words), as they are assigned a single vector that represents an average of all its meanings. Words with multiple meanings may cause ambiguity in the vector space, leading to incorrect word associations. For example, the word "bank" has two distinct meanings: a financial institution and the shape of a river edge. A financial institution does not typically have a physical relationship with a river edge, but due to the distributional hypothesis, it may appear that they are related. This can cause issues in tasks such as natural language inference, named entity recognition, and word sense disambiguation.

Static word embeddings may also struggle with words that have completely different meanings (homonymous words). Completely unrelated meanings for a word may appear to have a spurious correlation, where the word embedding incorrectly suggests a relationship between unrelated words. For example, "bark" refers to the sound made by dogs in one meaning, and tree bark in another meaning. The word embeddings for "dog" and "tree" may not have any apparent relationship, but they may be equidistant from the word embedding for "bark", causing confusion.

To address these issues, multi-sense embeddings have been developed. Multi-sense embeddings learn embeddings for each distinct meaning of polysemous and homonymous words separately. By assigning separate embeddings for each word sense, multi-sense embeddings avoid the issues caused by assuming unrelated word meanings to be related based on their distribution in text. However, multi-sense embeddings require additional data to be passed into the algorithm to disambiguate words, unlike static word embeddings which require no additional data.

--- Models

Two common models for multi-sense embeddings are MSSG and NP-MSSG. MSSG uses a mixture of Gaussians model, where each word sense is assigned a probability based on the context in which it appears. The algorithm for MSSG is similar to the algorithm used to infer parts-of-speech in Hidden Markov Models. The NP-MSSG model builds upon MSSG by addressing the limitation that MSSG cannot distinguish word senses based on the noun phrase structure. NP-MSSG analyzes the syntactic structure of a sentence to determine the correct word sense for ambiguous words. For example, NP-MSSG would be able to distinguish between the verb "bank" in the phrase "John went to the bank" (financial institution) and the noun "bank" in the phrase "The bank of the river" (river edge) .

Another approach to multi-sense embeddings is taken by models such as GenSen, MSWE, LAD, Paragram, and MUSE, which use a pre-trained language model to find the most likely word senses in a sentence. GenSen is one of the first models to use a pre-trained language model to disambiguate word senses. It uses the pre-trained language model to predict the probability of each word sense for every polysemous word in a sentence. GenSen then calculates the likelihood of each word sense by comparing the frequency of word sense co-occurrences in sentences to the frequency of those words occurring. The frequencies are calculated using Bayes' theorem. The probabilities of each word sense are then used to create word embeddings for each word in a sentence using a weighted sum. Only polysemous words are assigned multiple word embeddings, while non-polysemous words are treated the same as in standard word embedding models.

For English, multi-sense embeddings can be obtained using the TAL multi-sense embeddings online generator, which implements the GenSen algorithm.

 For biological sequences

Word embeddings can be generalized to work with any sequence of tokens, including DNA, RNA, and protein sequences in bioinformatics. In the case of protein sequences, words can be defined as either individual amino acids or k-mers, which are sequences of amino acids. When the words are defined as k-mers, embeddings for different values of k can be stacked on top of each other to form a 3D matrix. This 3D matrix can be flattened into a 2D matrix to be analyzed using techniques such as singular value decomposition. On the task of predicting protein structure from the amino acid sequence, this approach achieved state-of-the-art results in May 2021.

 Software

* Word2vec – an implementation of the Continuous Bag-of-Words (CBOW) and Skip-gram models by Tomas Mikolov at Google
* Gensim – a Python implementation of the Continuous Bag-of-Words (CBOW) and Skip-gram models, with an API for easy loading of Word2Vec Google news dataset
* GloVe – an implementation of Global Vectors for Word Representation (GloVe) by Stanford University
* fastText – an implementation of fastText by Facebook's AI Research
* PyTorch - an implementation of the Word2Vec model and GloVe by Facebook's AI Research
* Allennlp - An implementation of the ElMo model
* SpaCy – word embeddings for thespaCy library, including pre-trained models for English and German
* TensorFlow - an implementation of the Word2Vec model and GloVe

 Examples of application

* Search engines
* Sentiment analysis
* Machine translation
* Information retrieval
* Text classification
* Question answering systems
* Chatbots
* Image captioning
* Video description

 Ethical implications

A common issue with word embeddings is that they often reflect harmful stereotypes due to the biased training data. For example, a study found that word embeddings trained on English texts from 1860 to 2019 contained increasing amounts of gender bias. Another study found that many commonly used word embeddings contained age bias, with words associated with older age groups being associated with negative attributes such as "alone" and "dying". Such biases can lead to discriminatory outcomes, for example, a study found that predictive policing tools used by law enforcement disproportionately targeted minority neighborhoods due to biased training data. Since word embeddings are heavily dependent on the training data, they can reflect both the linguistic structure of a language and the societal biases present in that language. Therefore, debiasing word embeddings is an active area of research.

Introduction
Bidirectional encoder representations from transformers (BERT) is a language model introduced in October 2018 by researchers at Google. It learns to represent text as a sequence of vectors using self-supervised learning. It uses the encoder-only transformer architecture. BERT dramatically improved the state-of-the-art for large language models. As of 2020, BERT is a ubiquitous baseline in natural language processing (NLP) experiments. 
BERT is trained by masked token prediction and next sentence prediction. As a result of this training process, BERT learns contextual, latent representations of tokens in their context, similar to ELMo and GPT-2. It found applications for many natural language processing tasks, such as coreference resolution and polysemy resolution. It is an evolutionary step over ELMo, and spawned the study of "BERTology", which attempts to interpret what is learned by BERT.
BERT was originally implemented in the English language at two model sizes, BERTBASE (110 million parameters) and BERTLARGE (340 million parameters). Both were trained on the Toronto BookCorpus (800M words) and English Wikipedia  (2,500M words). The weights were released on GitHub. On March 11, 2020, 24 smaller models were released, the smallest being BERTTINY with just 4 million parameters.Architecture
BERT is an "encoder-only" transformer architecture. At a high level, BERT consists of 4 modules: 

Tokenizer: This module converts a piece of English text into a sequence of integers ("tokens").
Embedding: This module converts the sequence of tokens into an array of real-valued vectors representing the tokens. It represents the conversion of discrete token types into a lower-dimensional Euclidean space.
Encoder: a stack of Transformer blocks with self-attention, but without causal masking.
Task head: This module converts the final representation vectors into one-hot encoded tokens again by producing a predicted probability distribution over the token types. It can be viewed as a simple decoder, decoding the latent representation into token types, or as an "un-embedding layer".
The task head is necessary for pre-training, but it is often unnecessary for so-called "downstream tasks," such as question answering or sentiment classification. Instead, one removes the task head and replaces it with a newly initialized module suited for the task, and finetune the new module. The latent vector representation of the model is directly fed into this new module, allowing for sample-efficient transfer learning.Embedding
This section describes the embedding used by BERTBASE. The other one, BERTLARGE, is similar, just larger.
The tokenizer of BERT is WordPiece, which is a sub-word strategy like byte pair encoding. Its vocabulary size is 30,000, and any token not appearing in its vocabulary is replaced by [UNK] ("unknown"). 

The first layer is the embedding layer, which contains three components: token type embeddings, position embeddings, and segment type embeddings. 

Token type: The token type is a standard embedding layer, translating a one-hot vector into a dense vector based on its token type.
Position: The position embeddings are based on a token's position in the sequence. BERT uses absolute position embeddings, where each position in sequence is mapped to a real-valued vector. Each dimension of the vector consists of a sinusoidal function that takes the position in the sequence as input.
Segment type: Using a vocabulary of just 0 or 1, this embedding layer produces a dense vector based on whether the token belongs to the first or second text segment in that input. In other words, type-1 tokens are all tokens that appear after the [SEP] special token. All prior tokens are type-0.
The three embedding vectors are added together representing the initial token representation as a function of these three pieces of information. After embedding, the vector representation is normalized using a LayerNorm operation, outputting a 768-dimensional vector for each input token. After this, the representation vectors are passed forward through 12 Transformer encoder blocks, and are decoded back to 30,000-dimensional vocabulary space using a basic affine transformation layer.Architectural family

Pre-training
BERT was pre-trained simultaneously on two tasks.

Masked Language Model (MLM): In this task, BERT randomly masks some words in a sentence and tries to predict the original words that were masked. For example, in the sentence "The cat sat on the [MASK]," BERT would need to predict "mat." This helps BERT learn bidirectional context, meaning it understands the relationships between words not just from left to right or right to left but from both directions at the same time.
Next Sentence Prediction (NSP): In this task, BERT is trained to predict whether one sentence logically follows another. For example, given two sentences, "The cat sat on the mat." and "It was a sunny day," BERT has to decide if the second sentence is a valid continuation of the first one. This helps BERT understand relationships between sentences, which is important for tasks like question answering or document classification.Masked language modeling

The dataset shift problem arises when the distribution of inputs seen during training differs significantly from the distribution encountered during inference. A trained BERT model might be applied to word representation (like Word2Vec), where it would be run over sentences not containing any [MASK] tokens. It is later found that more diverse training objectives are generally better.

with probability 10%, the chosen token is replaced by a uniformly sampled random token, such as "happy", resulting in "my1 dog2 is3 happy4";
with probability 10%, nothing is done, resulting in "my1 dog2 is3 cute4".
After processing the input text, the model's 4th output vector is passed to its decoder layer, which outputs a probability distribution over its 30,000-dimensional vocabulary space.Next sentence prediction
Given two spans of text, the model predicts if these two spans appeared sequentially in the training corpus, outputting either [IsNext] or [NotNext]. The first span starts with a special token [CLS] (for "classify"). The two spans are separated by a special token [SEP] (for "separate"). After processing the two spans, the 1-st output vector (the vector coding for [CLS]) is passed to a separate neural network for the binary classification into [IsNext] and [NotNext].

For example, given "[CLS] my dog is cute [SEP] he likes playing" the model should output token [IsNext].
Given "[CLS] my dog is cute [SEP] how do magnets work" the model should output token [NotNext].Fine-tuning
BERT is meant as a general pretrained model for various applications in natural language processing. That is, after pre-training, BERT can be fine-tuned with fewer resources on smaller datasets to optimize its performance on specific tasks such as natural language inference and text classification, and sequence-to-sequence-based language generation tasks such as question answering and conversational response generation.
The original BERT paper published results demonstrating that a small amount of finetuning (for BERTLARGE, 1 hour on 1 Cloud TPU) allowed it to achieved state-of-the-art performance on a number of natural language understanding tasks:

GLUE (General Language Understanding Evaluation) task set (consisting of 9 tasks);
SQuAD (Stanford Question Answering Dataset) v1.1 and v2.0;
SWAG (Situations With Adversarial Generations).
In the original paper, all parameters of BERT are finetuned, and recommended that, for downstream applications that are text classifications, the output token at the [CLS] input token is fed into a linear-softmax layer to produce the label outputs.
The original code base defined the final linear layer as a "pooler layer", in analogy with global pooling in computer vision, even though it simply discards all output tokens except the one corresponding to  [CLS] .Cost
BERT was trained on the BookCorpus (800M words) and a filtered version of English Wikipedia (2,500M words) without lists, tables, and headers.
Training BERTBASE  on 4 cloud TPU (16 TPU chips total) took 4 days, at an estimated cost of 500 USD. Training BERTLARGE on 16 cloud TPU (64 TPU chips total) took 4 days.Interpretation
Language models like ELMo, GPT-2, and BERT, spawned the study of "BERTology", which attempts to interpret what is learned by these models. Their performance on these natural language understanding tasks are not yet well understood. Several research publications in 2018 and 2019 focused on investigating the relationship behind BERT's output as a result of carefully chosen input sequences, analysis of internal vector representations through probing classifiers, and the relationships represented by attention weights.
The high performance of the BERT model could also be attributed to the fact that it is bidirectionally trained. This means that BERT, based on the Transformer model architecture, applies its self-attention mechanism to learn information from a text from the left and right side during training, and consequently gains a deep understanding of the context. For example, the word fine can have two different meanings depending on the context (I feel fine today, She has fine blond hair). BERT considers the words surrounding the target word fine from the left and right side.
However it comes at a cost: due to encoder-only architecture lacking a decoder, BERT can't be prompted and can't generate text, while bidirectional models in general do not work effectively without the right side, thus being difficult to prompt. As an illustrative example, if one wishes to use BERT to continue a sentence fragment "Today, I went to", then naively one would mask out all the tokens as "Today, I went to  [MASK]  [MASK]  [MASK] ...  [MASK] ." where the number of  [MASK]  is the length of the sentence one wishes to extend to. However, this constitutes a dataset shift, as during training, BERT has never seen sentences with that many tokens masked out. Consequently, its performance degrades. More sophisticated techniques allow text generation, but at a high computational cost.History
BERT was originally published by Google researchers Jacob Devlin, Ming-Wei Chang, Kenton Lee, and Kristina Toutanova. The design has its origins from pre-training contextual representations, including semi-supervised sequence learning, generative pre-training, ELMo, and ULMFit. Unlike previous models, BERT is a deeply bidirectional, unsupervised language representation, pre-trained using only a plain text corpus. Context-free models such as word2vec or GloVe generate a single word embedding representation for each word in the vocabulary, whereas BERT takes into account the context for each occurrence of a given word. For instance, whereas the vector for "running" will have the same word2vec vector representation for both of its occurrences in the sentences "He is running a company" and "He is running a marathon", BERT will provide a contextualized embedding that will be different according to the sentence.
On October 25, 2019, Google announced that they had started applying BERT models for English language search queries within the US. On December 9, 2019, it was reported that BERT had been adopted by Google Search for over 70 languages. In October 2020, almost every single English-based query was processed by a BERT model.Variants
The BERT models were influential and inspired many variants.
RoBERTa (2019) was an engineering improvement. It preserves BERT's architecture (slightly larger, at 355M parameters), but improves its training, changing key hyperparameters, removing the next-sentence prediction task, and using much larger mini-batch sizes. 
DistilBERT (2019) distills BERTBASE to a model with just 60% of its parameters (66M), while preserving 95% of its benchmark scores. Similarly, TinyBERT (2019) is a distilled model with just 28% of its parameters.
ALBERT (2019) used shared-parameter across layers, and experimented with independently varying the hidden size and the word-embedding layer's output size as two hyperparameters. They also replaced the next sentence prediction task with the sentence-order prediction (SOP) task, where the model must distinguish the correct order of two consecutive text segments from their reversed order.

# Introduction

Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers, or BERT, is a bidirectional, unsupervised, pre-training approach for natural language processing (NLP) released by Google in 2018.

BERT is based on the transformer attention mechanism and uses two-way context word representations. It is trained directly on raw text using two pre-training tasks: (1) predicting words from masked words in the text and (2) determining whether two sentences form a correct pair. These pre-training tasks are based on the cased (uppercased) version of the BooksCorpus (800M words), Wikipedia (2500M words), and C4 (truncated news articles, 2400B tokens). BERT is then fine-tuned on supervised tasks such as named entity recognition, coreference resolution, and sentiment analysis.

Since 2018, BERT has achieved state-of-the-art results across 11 natural language understanding tasks, including question answering, natural language inference, and sentiment analysis. In 2019, BERT was selected as the default architecture for the Google RankBrain search algorithm, which is responsible for processing 15% of search queries. As of April 2021, BERT is still the most widely-used language model, with over 380 open-source implementations available in various languages, including Python, Java, Go, JavaScript, and Rust.

The name BERT comes from the German words for "big" and "bear", reflecting the model's size and Google's desire for the model to understand German language as well as a big bear.

## Architecture

BERT is based on the transformer architecture, a deep learning technique that uses self-attention to weight the importance of different words in a sentence when encoding their meanings. BERT is an "encoder-only" model, meaning that it uses self-attention to combine information from all parts of the input sequence when encoding any given part of the sequence. This is in contrast to decoder-only models, like the next-word predictor Autoregressive Language Model (ALM), which only consider prior words when computing the probability of any given word in a generated sequence. BERT may also be viewed as an "unidirectional" transformer, because the self-attention operation can be viewed as comparing each word in the sequence to every other, including itself; future work has instead compared each word to a limited subset of preceding words, resulting in faster computation.

BERT uses two versions of the transformer block, a basic building unit of the transformer, each doing basically the same thing but at different speeds. The two versions are called "BERT Self-Attention" and "Fast BERT Self-Attention". BERT Self-Attention is identical to the self-attention operation used in the original transformer paper, while Fast BERT Self-Attention replaces the dot product attention of the original formulation with a faster, less memory-intensive linear attention operation.

BERT has 12 layers (also referred to as depth), 12 attention heads, and 110 million parameters. There are three variants of the model: BERT Base (pre-training model: 12-layer, 768-hidden, 110M parameter), BERT Large (pre-training model: 24-layer, 1024-hidden, 340M parameter), and BERT (Small/Mini) (fine-tuning model only: 6-layer, 512-hidden, 35M parameter). Each layer in BERT has 768 hidden dimensions, and each head in BERT has 64 hidden dimensions (except for the last layer, which has 32). The hidden vectors are of dimension 768 for BERT Base and 1024 for BERT Large. The authors released both a base-sized model (12 layers) and a large-sized model (24 layers) for each of the two tasks. For the masked language model task, two versions of the model were trained: one model using the cased version of the vocabulary and one model using the uncased version. The two versions of the BERT Large model have 340 million parameters, while the BERT Base model has only 110 million parameters. A smaller, fast version of BERT (referred to as BERT Small or BERT Mini) was created by DistilBert, which removed half of the hidden layers of BERT while fine-tuning the remaining ones to maintain performance.

## Embedding

The input is first converted into a vector of real numbers using an embedding layer. BERT uses a combination of three types of embeddings: token, segment, and positional.

The token embedding maps the words into vectors of size 768 (for BERT Base) or 1024 (for BERT Large). BERT uses the WordPiece embedding, where a token is split into several subwords (or "pieces"). The vocabulary consists of 30,000 of the most common tokens in the English language, plus additional rare tokens. The vocabulary is the same for all BERT models.

The segment embedding is a binary mask that indicates which words belong to the first sentence and which belong to the second sentence (when dealing with the next sentence prediction task). It is a vector of size 2.

The position embedding maps a word's position in the sentence into a vector of real numbers. For example, the position embedding vector for the first word is $v_{position}(1) = (-0.2, 0.5, -1.0, ...)$, the second word is $v_{position}(2) = (0.2, -0.5, 1.0, ...)$, and so on. This is necessary because the transformer architecture is a recurrent network and order information is lost. The position embedding matrix is shared by all layers. So, for example, the position embedding of the first word "the" and the position embedding of the first occurrence of the word "the" two paragraphs later could be different vectors in ℝ^d.

The final embedding is the sum of the three individual embeddings ($\oplus$):

$\mathbf {E} _{i}=\mathbf {W} _{token}^{T}\mathbf {t} _{i}+\mathbf {W} _{segment}^{T}\mathbf {s} _{j}+\mathbf {W} _{position}^{T}\mathbf {p} _{k}$,

where $\mathbf {E}$ is the final embedding, $\mathbf {W} _{token}$, $\mathbf {W} _{segment}$, and $\mathbf {W} _{position}$ are the matrices for the three types of embeddings as described above, $\mathbf {t}$ is the token embedding, $\mathbf {s}$ is the segment embedding, and $\mathbf {p}$ is the position embedding. The indices i, j, and k are included to show that the embeddings can be unrolled into sequences of vectors.

## Training

The BERT model is trained in two stages. First, a pre-training stage trains the model on a large corpus of unlabeled text. Next, a fine-tuning stage trains the model on a specific natural language task, such as question answering or sentiment analysis. The pre-training stage consists of two tasks: (1) Masked Language Modeling (MLM) and (2) Next Sentence Prediction (NSP).

For the masked language modeling task, some proportion (typically 15%) of the words in a text corpus are randomly masked. The model learns to predict what the actual words are. Specifically, the model predicts the original word from the masked word and the context words before and after the masked word. Thus, the MLM task trains the model to learn the distribution of words conditioned on other words in the sentence. The proportion of words to mask is determined via a hyperparameter.

For the next sentence prediction task, two consecutive sentences from the original text are fed into the model. Sometimes, the second sentence may not follow the first one (e.g., "Joe entered the room. The moon is made of cheese."). The model has to learn to identify that the second sentence is unlikely to follow the first sentence.

After the pre-training stage, the BERT model is now ready to be fine-tuned for a specific NLP task. For most tasks, the parameters of the pre-trained model are frozen and only the parameters of the classifier on top of BERT are trained from scratch. However, for tasks such as span extraction or named entity recognition, the model keeps fine-tuning all the parameters of the BERT model.

## Pre-training

BERT's pre-training approach is based on the idea of self-supervised learning, where the model learns from a large corpus of unlabeled text. The method used in BERT is called Masked Language Modeling (MLM) and Next Sentence Prediction (NSP).

### Masked Language Model

The MLM task trains the model to learn the distribution of words conditioned on other words in the sentence. A proportion (e.g., 15%) of input tokens are randomly masked, and the model is trained to predict what the actual words are.

### Next Sentence Prediction

The NSP task trains the model to understand the relationship between two sentences. The model is trained on paired sentences from a large corpus of text (e.g., Wikipedia). The model has to learn to identify whether the second sentence that follows the first sentence is a subsequent sentence in the original text or a randomly chosen unrelated sentence.

## Masked language modeling

In the masked language modeling (MLM) task, some proportion of the input tokens are masked and replaced with a [MASK] token. The model is then trained to predict the original tokens from the masked tokens and the context. This is done using the following formula:

$P(\mathbf {t} _i^{'}|\mathbf {t} _i,\mathbf {t} _i^l,\mathbf {t} _i^r)=softmax_{w}\exp({\mathbf {E} _{i}^{l}\cdot \mathbf {w} +\mathbf {E} _{i}^{r}\cdot \mathbf {w} +\mathbf {e} _{t}})/Z$

where $\mathbf {E}$ is the embedding matrix, $\mathbf {t}$ is the input token sequence, $t_i^l$ and $t_i^r$ are the left and right context of the masked token $t_i$, $\mathbf {E} ^l$ and $\mathbf {E} ^r$ are the mean embedding of the left and right context, $\mathbf {e}$ is the standard embedding for the [MASK] token, w is a vector of size 768 (or 1024), and Z is the partition function. The model is trained using stochastic gradient descent.

This approach differs from the next word prediction task used to train language models such as GPT-1 and GPT-2. In the MLM approach, the model is trained to predict all possible tokens from the masked token, while in the next word prediction approach, the model is trained to predict only one possible next token. The MLM approach has the advantage that it takes into account the context from both sides of the masked token while the next word prediction only takes into account the context from the previous tokens.

The MLM task is designed to make the model learn bidirectional word representations. This is important because most of the previous NLP models, such as word2vec and GloVe, have learned word representations that are only context-independent. The bidirectional representations learned by BERT have shown to improve the performance of many NLP tasks.

## Next sentence prediction

In the next sentence prediction task, a pair of sentences $(\mathbf {u} ,\mathbf {v} )$ is fed into the model, where $\mathbf {u}$ is the first sentence and $\mathbf {v}$ is the second sentence. The goal of the model is to learn the probability that $\mathbf {v}$ is the next sentence that follows $\mathbf {u}$ in the original text. The model is trained using two sentences from the original text: the next sentence $\mathbf {v}$ and the random sentence $\mathbf {w}$. The model has to learn to assign a higher probability to $\mathbf {v}$ since it is paired with $\mathbf {u}$ in the original text, and a lower probability to $\mathbf {w}$ since it is not.

Formally, let f_θ be the NSP model with parameters θ, $\mathbf {u}$ and $\mathbf {v}$ be two sentences. The probability that $\mathbf {v}$ is the next sentence after $\mathbf {u}$ is given by:

$P_{\theta }(\mathbf {v} |\mathbf {u} )={\frac {\exp(f_{\theta }(\mathbf {u} ,\mathbf {v} ))}{\exp(f_{\theta }(\mathbf {u} ,\mathbf {v} ))+\exp(f_{\theta }(\mathbf {u} ,\mathbf {w} ))}}$

The model is trained to maximize the log-likelihood of the correct next sentence using stochastic gradient ascent.

## Fine-tuning

Fine-tuning BERT refers to the process of adapting the pre-trained BERT model to a specific natural language processing (NLP) task. This is done by training the BERT model further on task-specific data, allowing the model to learn task-specific representations and improve its performance on the task.

There are two main approaches to fine-tuning BERT: training the entire model and fine-tuning only the top layers. In the training-the-whole-model approach, all the parameters of the BERT model are updated during training. This approach is computationally expensive and requires a large amount of memory, but it allows the model to learn new representations from scratch and adapt to the task at hand.

In the fine-tune-only-top-layers approach, only the parameters of the top layers of the BERT model are updated during training. The parameters of the lower layers are kept fixed, which means they are not updated during training. This approach is computationally cheaper and requires less memory than training the whole model, but it assumes that the lower layers contain general-purpose representations that can be useful for many tasks.

Once the BERT model is fine-tuned, it can be used to make predictions on new data. The fine-tuned model is expected to perform better than the pre-trained model on the specific task it was fine-tuned for.

## Cost

The cost of training BERT consists of the cost of pre-training and the cost of fine-tuning. The pre-training cost is very high due to the large amount of data and compute required. The pre-training of BERT Large, for instance, was done on 16 TPUv2 chips for 4 days, and the pre-training of RoBERTa took 200,000 GPU hours. The fine-tuning cost depends on the size of the fine-tuning dataset and the complexity of the task. Fine-tuning BERT usually requires less data and computation than training a model from scratch.

## Interpretation

The BERT model has been the subject of much scrutiny since its introduction in 2018. One of the main challenges in interpreting BERT is the complexity of the model. BERT is a deep, non-linear model with multiple layers and parameters, making it difficult to understand how the model makes predictions. Another challenge is the size of BERT, which contains millions of parameters. This makes it difficult to visualize and interpret the model's decision-making process.

One approach to interpreting BERT is to use attention visualization. Attention visualization involves visualizing the attention weights that BERT assigns to different words in a sentence. This can give insight into which words the model finds important when making a prediction. Attention visualization has been used to show that BERT attends to different parts of a sentence than a traditional parser, and that it can capture complex dependencies in the data.

Another approach to interpreting BERT is to use probing tasks. Probing tasks involve training a simple classifier on the representations learned by BERT and evaluating the classifier's performance on a downstream task. This can give insight into what information BERT has learned. Probing tasks have been used to show that BERT learns to capture a wide range of linguistic phenomena, including morphology, syntax, and semantics.

Despite the progress made in interpreting BERT, there are still many open questions. One open question is how to interpret the representations learned by BERT in a way that is meaningful to humans. Another open question is how to interpret the predictions made by BERT. This is challenging because BERT is a black box model, and it is not clear what factors influence its predictions.

A third open question is how to interpret the results of fine-tuning BERT. Fine-tuning BERT involves updating the pre-trained representations with task-specific information, but it is not clear how this process affects the representations learned by the model.

Finally, a fourth open question is how to interpret the results of ensemble methods that use BERT as a component. Ensemble methods can improve the performance of BERT, but it is not clear how the different models in the ensemble interact with each other or how the ensemble as a whole makes predictions.

These open questions highlight the need for more research on interpreting BERT. Addressing these questions will require developing new methods for visualizing and understanding the representations learned by BERT and the predictions it makes.

## History

BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) is a bidirectional, unsupervised, and pre-training approach to natural language processing (NLP) that was introduced in 2018 by Devlin, et al. at Google AI. BERT is based on the transformer architecture, which uses self-attention to weigh the importance of different words in a sentence when encoding their meanings. Unlike previous NLP models that were trained with either a left-to-right or a right-to-left approach, BERT is bidirectional because it uses self-attention to encode the context around a word. This means that BERT can capture both the forward and backward context of a word, giving it a more comprehensive understanding of the word's meaning.

BERT was pre-trained on two tasks: masked language modeling (MLM) and next sentence prediction (NSP). MLM is a task where a portion of the input text is masked, and the model has to predict the masked tokens. NSP is a task where the model has to predict whether two given sentences appear consecutively in their original text. BERT was trained on these two tasks using a large corpus of text, including books and Wikipedia pages. The pre-training phase of BERT allows the model to learn general-purpose language representations that can be applied to a wide range of NLP tasks.

After pre-training, BERT can be fine-tuned on specific NLP tasks, such as sentiment analysis, named entity recognition, and question answering. Fine-tuning involves adjusting the pre-trained model parameters on a task-specific dataset to improve performance. BERT has been shown to achieve state-of-the-art or competitive results on a variety of NLP tasks with minimal fine-tuning.

One of the advantages of BERT is its simplicity. BERT does not require task-specific architectural modifications or large amounts of labeled data for training. Instead, it relies on pre-training to learn general language representations that can be adapted to different tasks through fine-tuning. This makes BERT a flexible and efficient solution for a wide range of NLP tasks.

Since its introduction in 2018, BERT has become one of the most popular and widely-used NLP models. Its success has led to the development of many variants and extensions of the BERT architecture, including RoBERTa, ALBERT, and BERT++. These models build upon the BERT architecture and aim to improve its performance and efficiency further.

Overall, BERT has had a significant impact on the field of NLP, demonstrating the effectiveness of pre-training and bidirectional context in language representation learning. Its simplicity, flexibility, and strong performance have made it a popular choice for a wide range of NLP tasks.

## Variants

The original BERT architecture was introduced in 2018, and since then, many variants and extensions of the architecture have been developed. Some notable variants of BERT include:

* RoBERTa: RoBERTa (Robustly Optimized BERT Pretraining Approach) is a variant of BERT that was developed by Facebook's AI research group. RoBERTa builds on top of BERT by removing the masking of training data and changing the batch normalization with dropout. RoBERTa has achieved state-of-the-art results on several natural language understanding tasks, including the General Language Understanding Evaluation (GLUE) and General Language Understanding Evaluation (SQuAD) datasets.
* ALBERT: ALBERT (A Lite BERT) is a variant of BERT that was developed by Google. ALBERT is a smaller and more efficient version of BERT that achieves similar performance with less parameter usage. ALBERT achieves this by employing shared parameters for the same layers and input embeddings.
* SpanBERT: SpanBERT is a variant of BERT that was developed by the authors of the original BERT paper. SpanBERT is specifically designed for span-level NLP tasks, such as named entity recognition and relation classification. SpanBERT improves upon BERT by masking entire spans of tokens instead of individual tokens, which allows it to better capture the context of spans.
* RoBERTa-Large: RoBERTa-large is a larger variant of RoBERTa that was trained with the same principles as the original RoBERTa model but with a larger number of parameters. RoBERTa-large has 355M parameters and was trained on 16 Tesla V100 GPUs for 3 days. RoBERTa-large has achieved state-of-the-art results on several natural language understanding tasks, including the General Language Understanding Evaluation (GLUE) and General Language Understanding Evaluation (SQuAD) datasets.
* ALBERT-Base: ALBERT-base is a smaller variant of ALBERT that was developed by Google. ALBERT-base has 12 layers, 12 attention heads, and 110M parameters, which makes it a much smaller model than BERT-base. ALBERT-base was trained on a large corpus of English text and has achieved state-of-the-art results on several NLP tasks, including the CoNLL-2003 named entity recognition task and the AG News classification task.
* SpanBERT-large: SpanBERT-large is a larger variant of SpanBERT that was developed by the authors of the original SpanBERT paper. SpanBERT-large has 24 layers, 16 attention heads, and 384M parameters, and it has achieved state-of-the-art results on several NLP tasks, including the CoNLL-2003 named entity recognition task and the OntoNotes relation classification task.
* DistilBERT: DistilBERT is a distilled version of BERT that was developed by the Hugging Face team. DistilBERT is a smaller and faster version of BERT that retains most of BERT's performance. DistilBERT achieves this by training a smaller model on top of the pre-trained BERT model using knowledge distillation.
* BERT-wwm: BERT-wwm is a variant of BERT that was developed for the Chinese language. BERT-wwm improves upon the original BERT model by incorporating a Wordpiece Masking strategy and an Embedding Lookahead Mechanism. BERT-wwm has achieved state-of-the-art results on several Chinese language NLP tasks, including the Chinese GLUE benchmark and the MSRA named entity recognition task.
* BERT-JIEBA: BERT-JIEBA is a variant of BERT that was developed for the Chinese language. BERT-JIEBA is trained on top of the JIEBA segmentation tool, which is a popular Chinese word segmentation tool. BERT-JIEBA has achieved state-of-the-art results on several Chinese language NLP tasks, including the MSRA named entity recognition task and the Weibo part-of-speech tagging task.
* RoBERTa-wwm: RoBERTa-wwm is a variant of RoBERTa that was developed for the Chinese language. RoBERTa-wwm improves upon the original RoBERTa model by incorporating a Wordpiece Masking strategy and an Embedding Lookahead Mechanism. RoBERTa-wwm has achieved state-of-the-art results on several Chinese language NLP tasks, including the Chinese GLUE benchmark and the MSRA named entity recognition task.

These are just a few examples of the many variants of BERT that have been developed. Each variant has its own strengths and weaknesses, and the best choice of model depends on the specific task and dataset.

* ↑ There are 300M tokens in the uncased version of BooksCorpus and 500M tokens in the cased version.
* ↑ The cased version of the vocabulary has 30,522 tokens, and the uncased version has 30,000 tokens.
* ↑ The hidden size is the dimensionality of the hidden states in the transformer blocks. It is also the number of features in the linear layer connecting the transformer blocks to the output layer.
* ↑ The number of attention heads is the number of attention mechanisms that run in parallel in the transformer blocks. Each attention mechanism attends to different parts of the input sequence when computing the weighted average of the hidden states.
* ↑ The feed-forward/ filter size is the dimensionality of the hidden layer in the position-wise feed-forward network in the transformer blocks. It is also the number of features in the linear layer connecting the input and output of the feed-forward network.
* ↑ The embedding size is the dimensionality of the embedding vectors in the embedding layer. It is also the number of features in the linear layer connecting the embedding layer to the transformer blocks.
* ↑ The sequence length is the maximum number of tokens in the input sequence. It is also the number of rows in the attention matrices.
* ↑ The number of parameters is the total number of trainable parameters in the model. It is the sum of the parameters in the embedding layer, the transformer blocks, and the output layer.
* ↑ The batch size is the number of input sequences processed by the model at once during training. It determines the computational workload per iteration and the utilization of available hardware (e.g., GPU) memory.
* ↑ The number of epochs is the number of times the entire training dataset is passed through the model during training. It determines how long the model is trained for and the potential for overfitting to the training data.
* ↑ The learning rate is the step size used by the optimizer to update the model parameters during training. It determines how quickly the model learns from the training data and can affect convergence and performance.
* ↑ The training time is the amount of time required to train the model on the specified hardware. It can vary depending on the size and complexity of the model, the training dataset, and the hardware specifications.
* ↑ The GPU memory usage is the amount of graphics processing unit (GPU) memory required by the model during training. It can affect the batch size and sequence length that can be used and the availability of multiple GPUs for training.
* ↑ The training data size is the amount of labeled data used to train the model. It can affect the model's performance and generalization to new data.
* ↑ The model performance is evaluated on a held-out test dataset using appropriate metrics for the task, such as accuracy, F1 score, or mean squared error.
