Introduction
The transformer is a deep learning architecture that was developed by researchers at Google and is based on the multi-head attention mechanism, which was proposed in the 2017 paper "Attention Is All You Need". Text is converted to numerical representations called tokens, and each token is converted into a vector via lookup from a word embedding table. At each layer, each token is then contextualized within the scope of the context window with other (unmasked) tokens via a parallel multi-head attention mechanism, allowing the signal for key tokens to be amplified and less important tokens to be diminished.
Transformers have the advantage of having no recurrent units, therefore requiring less training time than earlier recurrent neural architectures (RNNs) such as long short-term memory (LSTM). Later variations have been widely adopted for training large language models (LLM) on large (language) datasets.

Transformers were first developed as an improvement over previous architectures for machine translation, but have found many applications since. They are used in large-scale natural language processing, computer vision (vision transformers), reinforcement learning, audio, multimodal learning, robotics, and even playing chess. It has also led to the development of pre-trained systems, such as generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and BERT (bidirectional encoder representations from transformers).History
Predecessors
For many years, sequence modelling and generation was done by using plain recurrent neural networks (RNNs). A well-cited early example was the Elman network (1990). In theory, the information from one token can propagate arbitrarily far down the sequence, but in practice the vanishing-gradient problem leaves the model's state at the end of a long sentence without precise, extractable information about preceding tokens.
A key breakthrough was LSTM (1995), a RNN which used various innovations to overcome the vanishing gradient problem, allowing efficient learning of long-sequence modelling. One key innovation was the use of an attention mechanism which used neurons that multiply the outputs of other neurons, so-called multiplicative units. Neural networks using multiplicative units were later called sigma-pi networks or higher-order networks. LSTM became the standard architecture for long sequence modelling until the 2017 publication of Transformers.
However, LSTM still used sequential processing, like most other RNNs. Specifically, RNNs operate one token at a time from first to last; they cannot operate in parallel over all tokens in a sequence. 
Modern Transformers overcome this problem, but unlike RNNs, they require computation time that is quadratic in the size of the context window. The linearly scaling fast weight controller (1992) learns to compute a weight matrix for further processing depending on the input. One of its two networks has "fast weights" or "dynamic links" (1981). A slow neural network learns by gradient descent to generate keys and values for computing the weight changes of the fast neural network which computes answers to queries. This was later shown to be equivalent to the unnormalized linear Transformer.Attention with seq2seq
The idea of encoder-decoder sequence transduction had been developed in the early 2010s (see previous papers). The papers most commonly cited as the originators that produced seq2seq are two concurrently published papers from 2014.
A 380M-parameter model for machine translation uses two long short-term memories (LSTM). Its architecture consists of two parts. The encoder is an LSTM that takes in a sequence of tokens and turns it into a vector. The decoder is another LSTM that converts the vector into a sequence of tokens. Similarly, another 130M-parameter model used gated recurrent units (GRU) instead of LSTM. Later research showed that GRUs are neither better nor worse than LSTMs for seq2seq.
These early seq2seq models had no attention mechanism, and the state vector is accessible only after the last word of the source text was processed. Although in theory such a vector retains the information about the whole original sentence, in practice the information is poorly preserved. This is because the input is processed sequentially by one recurrent network into a fixed-size output vector, which is then processed by another recurrent network into an output. If the input is long, then the output vector would not be able to contain all relevant information, degrading the output. As evidence, reversing the input sentence improved seq2seq translation.
The RNNsearch model introduced an attention mechanism to seq2seq for machine translation to solve the bottleneck problem (of the fixed-size output vector), allowing the model to process long-distance dependencies more easily. The name is because it "emulates searching through a source sentence during decoding a translation".
The relative performances were compared between global (that of RNNsearch) and local (sliding window) attention model architectures for machine translation, finding that mixed attention had higher quality than global attention, while local attention reduced translation time.
In 2016, Google Translate was revamped to Google Neural Machine Translation, which replaced the previous model based on statistical machine translation. The new model was a seq2seq model where the encoder and the decoder were both 8 layers of bidirectional LSTM. It took nine months to develop, and it outperformed the statistical approach, which took ten years to develop.Parallelizing attention
Seq2seq models with attention (including self-attention) still suffered from the same issue with recurrent networks, which is that they are hard to parallelize, which prevented them from being accelerated on GPUs. In 2016, decomposable attention applied a self-attention mechanism to feedforward networks, which are easy to parallelize, and achieved SOTA result in textual entailment with an order of magnitude fewer parameters than LSTMs. One of its authors, Jakob Uszkoreit, suspected that attention without recurrence is sufficient for language translation, thus the title "attention is all you need". That hypothesis was against conventional wisdom at the time, and even his father Hans Uszkoreit, a well-known computational linguist, was skeptical. In the same year, self-attention (called intra-attention or intra-sentence attention) was proposed for LSTMs.
In 2017, the original (100M-sized) encoder-decoder transformer model was proposed in the "Attention is all you need" paper. At the time, the focus of the research was on improving seq2seq for machine translation, by removing its recurrence to process all tokens in parallel, but preserving its dot-product attention mechanism to keep its text processing performance. This led to the introduction of a multi-head attention model that was easier to parallelize due to the use of independent heads and the lack of recurrence. Its parallelizability was an important factor to its widespread use in large neural networks.AI boom era
Already in spring 2017, even before the "Attention is all you need" preprint was published, one of the co-authors applied the "decoder-only" variation of the architecture to generate fictitious Wikipedia articles. Transformer architecture is now used alongside many generative models that contribute to the ongoing AI boom.
In language modelling, ELMo (2018) was a bi-directional LSTM that produces contextualized word embeddings, improving upon the line of research from bag of words and word2vec. It was followed by BERT (2018), an encoder-only Transformer model. In 2019 October, Google started using BERT to process search queries. In 2020, Google Translate replaced the previous RNN-encoder–RNN-decoder model by a Transformer-encoder–RNN-decoder model.
Starting in 2018, the OpenAI GPT series of decoder-only Transformers became state of the art in natural language generation. In 2022, a chatbot based on GPT-3, ChatGPT, became unexpectedly popular, triggering a boom around large language models.
Since 2020, Transformers have been applied in modalities beyond text, including the vision transformer, speech recognition, robotics, and multimodal. The vision transformer, in turn, stimulated new developments in convolutional neural networks. Image and video generators like DALL-E (2021), Stable Diffusion 3 (2024), and Sora (2024), use Transformers to analyse input data (like text prompts) by breaking it down into "tokens" and then calculating the relevance between each token using self-attention, which helps the model understand the context and relationships within the data.Training
Methods for stabilizing training
The plain transformer architecture had difficulty converging. In the original paper the authors recommended using learning rate warmup. That is, the learning rate should linearly scale up from 0 to maximal value for the first part of the training (usually recommended to be 2% of the total number of training steps), before decaying again.
A 2020 paper found that using layer normalization before (instead of after) multiheaded attention and feedforward layers stabilizes training, not requiring learning rate warmup.Pretrain-finetune
Transformers typically are first pretrained by self-supervised learning on a large generic dataset, followed by supervised fine-tuning on a small task-specific dataset. The pretrain dataset is typically an unlabeled large corpus, such as The Pile. Tasks for pretraining and fine-tuning commonly include:

language modeling
next-sentence prediction
question answering
reading comprehension
sentiment analysis
paraphrasing
The T5 transformer report documents a large number of natural language pretraining tasks. Some examples are:

restoring or repairing incomplete or corrupted text. For example, the input, "Thank you ~~ me to your party ~~ week", might generate the output, "Thank you for inviting me to your party last week".
translation between natural languages (machine translation)
judging the pragmatic acceptability of natural language. For example, the following sentence might be judged "not acceptable", because even though it is syntactically well-formed, it is improbable in ordinary human usage: The course is jumping well.
Note that while each of these tasks is trivial or obvious for human native speakers of the language (or languages), they have typically proved challenging for previous generations of machine learning architecture.Tasks
In general, there are 3 classes of language modelling tasks: "masked", "autoregressive", and "prefixLM". These classes are independent of a specific modeling architecture such as Transformer, but they are often discussed in the context of Transformer.
In a masked task, one or more of the tokens is masked out, and the model would produce a probability distribution predicting what the masked-out tokens are based on the context. The loss function for the task is typically sum of log-perplexities for the masked-out tokens:

In an autoregressive task, the entire sequence is masked at first, and the model produces a probability distribution for the first token. Then the first token is revealed and the model predicts the second token, and so on. The loss function for the task is still typically the same. All transformers have the same primary components:

Tokenizers, which convert text into tokens.
Embedding layer, which converts tokens and positions of the tokens into vector representations.
Transformer layers, which carry out repeated transformations on the vector representations, extracting more and more linguistic information. Like earlier seq2seq models, the original transformer model used an encoder-decoder architecture. The encoder consists of encoding layers that process all the input tokens together one layer after another, while the decoder consists of decoding layers that iteratively process the encoder's output and the decoder's output tokens so far.
The purpose of each encoder layer is to create contextualized representations of the tokens, where each representation corresponds to a token that "mixes" information from other input tokens via self-attention mechanism. Each decoder layer contains two attention sublayers: (1) cross-attention for incorporating the output of encoder (contextualized input token representations), and (2) self-attention for "mixing" information among the input tokens to the decoder (i.e. the tokens generated so far during inference time).
Both the encoder and decoder layers have a feed-forward neural network for additional processing of their outputs and contain residual connections and layer normalization steps. These feed-forward layers contain most of the parameters in a Transformer model.Feedforward network

A decoder consists of an embedding layer, followed by multiple decoder layers, followed by an un-embedding layer.
Each decoder consists of three major components: a causally masked self-attention mechanism, a cross-attention mechanism, and a feed-forward neural network. The decoder functions in a similar fashion to the encoder, but an additional attention mechanism is inserted which instead draws relevant information from the encodings generated by the encoders. This mechanism can also be called the encoder-decoder attention.
Like the first encoder, the first decoder takes positional information and embeddings of the output sequence as its input, rather than encodings. The transformer must not use the current or future output to predict an output, so the output sequence must be partially masked to prevent this reverse information flow. This allows for autoregressive text generation. For decoding, all-to-all attention is inappropriate, because a token cannot attend to tokens not yet generated. Thus, the self-attention module in the decoder is causally masked.
In contrast, the cross-attention mechanism attends to the output vectors of the encoder, which is computed before the decoder starts decoding. Consequently, there is no need for masking in the cross-attention mechanism.

The final points of detail are the residual connections and layer normalization (LayerNorm, or LN), which while conceptually unnecessary, are necessary for numerical stability and convergence.  
The residual connection, which is introduced to avoid vanishing gradient issues and stabilize the training process, can be expressed as follows: y = F(x) + x. The expression indicates that an output y is the sum of the transformation of input x (F(x)) and the input itself (x). Adding the input x can preserve the input information and avoid issues when the gradient of F(x) is close to zero.  
Similarly to how the feedforward network modules are applied individually to each vector, the LayerNorm is also applied individually to each vector.

The Transformer architecture, being modular, allows variations. Several common variations are described here.
An "encoder-only" Transformer applies the encoder to map an input text into a sequence of vectors that represent the input text. This is usually used for text embedding and representation learning for downstream applications. BERT is encoder-only. They are less often used currently, as they were found to be not significantly better than training an encoder-decoder Transformer, then taking just the encoder.
A "decoder-only" Transformer is not literally decoder-only, since without an encoder, the cross-attention mechanism has nothing to attend to. Thus, the decoder layers in a decoder-only Transformer is composed of just two sublayers: the causally masked self-attention, and the feedforward network. This is usually used for text generation and instruction following. The models in the GPT series and Chinchilla series are decoder-only.
An "encoder-decoder" Transformer is generally the same as the original Transformer, with 2 sublayers per encoder layer and 3 sublayers per decoder layer, etc. They might have minor architectural improvements, such as alternative activation functions, changing the location of normalization, etc. This is also usually used for text generation and instruction following. The models in the T5 series are encoder-decoder.

The transformer model has been implemented in standard deep learning frameworks such as TensorFlow and PyTorch. Transformers is a library produced by Hugging Face that supplies transformer-based architectures and pretrained models.KV caching
When an autoregressive transformer is used for inference, such as generating text, the query vector is different at each step, but the already-computed key and value vectors are always the same. Transformers can also be used/adapted for modalities (input or output) beyond just text, usually by finding a way to "tokenize" the modality.
Multimodal models can either be trained from scratch, or by finetuning. A 2022 study found that Transformers pretrained only on natural language can be finetuned on only 0.03% of parameters and become competitive with LSTMs on a variety of logical and visual tasks, demonstrating transfer learning. The LLaVA was a vision-language model composed of a language model (Vicuna-13B) and a vision model (ViT-L/14), connected by a linear layer. Only the linear layer is finetuned.
Vision transformers adapt the transformer to computer vision by breaking down input images as a series of patches, turning them into vectors, and treating them like tokens in a standard transformer.
Conformer and later Whisper follow the same pattern for speech recognition, first turning the speech signal into a spectrogram, which is then treated like an image, i.e. broken down into a series of patches, turned into vectors and treated like tokens in a standard transformer.
Perceivers are a variant of Transformers designed for multimodality.
For image generation, notable architectures are DALL-E 1 (2021), Parti (2022), Phenaki (2023), and Muse (2023). Unlike later models, DALL-E is not a diffusion model. Instead, it uses a decoder-only Transformer that autoregressively generates a text, followed by the token representation of an image, which is then converted by a variational autoencoder to an image. Parti is an encoder-decoder Transformer, where the encoder processes a text prompt, and the decoder generates a token representation of an image. Muse is an encoder-only Transformer that is trained to predict masked image tokens from unmasked image tokens. During generation, all input tokens are masked, and the highest-confidence predictions are included for the next iteration, until all tokens are predicted. Phenaki is a text-to-video model. It is a bidirectional masked transformer conditioned on pre-computed text tokens. The generated tokens are then decoded to a video.Applications
The transformer has had great success in natural language processing (NLP). Many large language models such as GPT-2, GPT-3, GPT-4, Gemini, AlbertAGPT, Claude, BERT, Grok, XLNet, RoBERTa and ChatGPT demonstrate the ability of transformers to perform a wide variety of NLP-related subtasks and their related real-world applications, including:

machine translation
time series prediction
document summarization
document generation
named entity recognition (NER)
writing computer code based on requirements expressed in natural language.
speech-to-text
Beyond traditional NLP, the transformer architecture has had success in other applications, such as:

biological sequence analysis
video understanding
protein folding (such as AlphaFold)
evaluating chess board positions. Using static evaluation alone (that is, with no Minimax search) transformer achieved an Elo of 2895, putting it at grandmaster level.See also

# Transformer (deep learning architecture)

In deep learning, the transformer is a deep-learning architecture introduced in the 2017 paper "Attention Is All You Need" by researchers at Google Brain. It serves as a breakthrough in machine translation, demonstrating that an architecture based solely on attention mechanisms can match or exceed the performance of traditional phrase-based machine translation systems.

The transformer improves on the multi-layer perceptron (MLP) architecture by adding a novel mechanism called attention, which allows the model to focus on different parts of the input when generating each part of the output. The transformer is a significant advancement over prior recurrent neural network (RNN)-based architectures, such as long short-term memory (LSTM) networks, which are less efficient at processing long sequences. Additionally, unlike RNNs, the transformer can attend to different positions in the input sequence in parallel, making it much faster to train and deploy.

The transformer has since become the de facto backbone architecture for many deep learning tasks involving sequences, especially in natural language processing (NLP). Its success led to widespread adoption of the transformer in large language models (LLMs) such as BERT, GPT, T5, and ChatGPT. The architecture has also been adapted for other purposes, such as computer vision, time series forecasting, and reinforcement learning.

History

The transformer model was introduced in the 2017 paper "Attention Is All You Need" by researchers at Google Brain. The paper demonstrated that a neural network based entirely on attention mechanisms could achieve state-of-the-art results on several tasks, including machine translation.

Attention mechanisms had been a promising area of research in deep learning for several years, with early work such as the additive attention mechanism for neural machine translation (NMT) by Bahdanau et al. in 2015. However, these early approaches were limited in their ability to scale to long sequences and were often combined with other architectures, such as LSTMs.

The transformer addressed these limitations by using a self-attention mechanism that allowed the model to weigh the importance of different parts of the input sequence when generating each part of the output sequence. This eliminated the need for recurrence or convolution, allowing the model to process entire sequences in parallel.

Since its introduction, the transformer has become one of the most widely used deep learning architectures. Its success has inspired numerous variations and extensions, such as the transformer encoder-decoder architecture for machine translation and the transformer-based BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) model for NLP. The transformer has also been adapted for other tasks, such as image processing and time series forecasting.

 Predecessors

--- Sequence modeling

Before the transformer, recurrent neural networks (RNNs), and particularly LSTMs, were the dominant approach for modeling sequences. RNNs process sequences in a sequential manner, with each output being fed back into the network along with the next input. LSTMs are a type of RNN that use gating mechanisms to better preserve information over longer sequences.

However, LSTMs have several limitations. They can be difficult to train, requiring careful initialization and often taking a long time to converge. They are also less efficient than other architectures, as the recurrent nature of the model requires processing sequences sequentially. Finally, LSTMs do not scale well to long sequences, as the recurrence can lead to either vanishing or exploding gradients.

--- Attention with seq2seq

Attention mechanisms were originally introduced in the sequence-to-sequence (seq2seq) architecture for machine translation by Luong et al. in 2015. The seq2seq architecture consists of an encoder-decoder architecture where the encoder produces a fixed-length representation of the input sequence, which is then decoded into the output sequence. The attention mechanism allows the decoder to focus on different parts of the input sequence when generating each part of the output sequence.

The attention mechanism computes a weighted sum of the encoder's hidden states, with the weights determined by the similarity between the decoder's current state and the encoder's hidden states. This allows the decoder to dynamically focus on different parts of the input sequence as it generates the output sequence, improving the model's ability to handle long sequences and capture complex relationships between input and output tokens.

Attention mechanisms proved to be a powerful addition to the seq2seq architecture, improving performance on machine translation tasks. This led to a flurry of research into different attention mechanisms and their applications to other sequence modeling tasks.

 Parallelizing attention

While attention mechanisms proved to be powerful, they were also computationally expensive and difficult to parallelize. This made them impractical for use in large-scale models or for tasks with long sequences.

The transformer addressed these limitations by using a self-attention mechanism that allowed the model to weigh the importance of different parts of the input sequence when generating each part of the output sequence. This eliminated the need for recurrence or convolution, allowing the model to process entire sequences in parallel.

In addition to the self-attention mechanism, the transformer also introduced a feed-forward network with residual connections and layer normalization, which improved the model's ability to learn and converge more quickly.

The success of the transformer in machine translation and other tasks led to a proliferation of variations and extensions to the basic architecture. These include the use of multi-head attention, which allows the model to attend to different parts of the input sequence using multiple attention mechanisms simultaneously; the use of position-wise feed-forward networks, which allow the model to process different parts of the input sequence in parallel; and the use of causal masking, which prevents the model from attending to future tokens during decoding.

Despite these advances, the transformer still had limitations. It was still relatively computationally expensive, making it difficult to use in resource-constrained settings. It was also difficult to parallelize, limiting its scalability to very large models or long sequences.

 Feedforward network

The feedforward network in the transformer architecture is a key component that enables the model to learn complex non-linear transformations of the input and output sequences. In the original transformer model, the feedforward network is composed of two fully connected layers with a non-linear activation function in between.

The feedforward network takes the output of the multi-head self-attention mechanism and applies a series of linear transformations to it. Specifically, the input to the feedforward network is first transformed using a weight matrix $W^{(1)}$ and a bias vector $b^{(1)}$, producing a new output:

    $y_1 = \text{ReLU}(xW^{(1)} + b^{(1)})$

where $\text{ReLU}$ is the rectified linear unit activation function. The output of the first linear transformation is then passed through another linear transformation, using a weight matrix $W^{(2)}$ and a bias vector $b^{(2)}$, to produce the final output of the feedforward network:

    $y_2 = y_1 W^{(2)} + b^{(2)}$

The feedforward network is applied separately to each position in the sequence, allowing the model to learn complex non-linear relationships between the input and output sequences. The use of the ReLU activation function introduces non-linearity to the model, enabling it to learn complex patterns in the data.

The feedforward network is an important component of the transformer architecture because it allows the model to learn complex transformations of the input and output sequences. By applying a series of linear transformations and non-linear activations, the feedforward network enables the model to capture complex relationships between the input and output sequences, leading to improved performance on a variety of tasks.

 Scaled dot-product attention

The scaled dot-product attention is a key component of the transformer architecture that allows the model to weigh the importance of different parts of the input sequence when generating each part of the output sequence. It is based on the dot-product attention mechanism introduced in the original attention paper by Bahdanau et al. in 2015, but with a scaling factor added to improve training stability.

The scaled dot-product attention takes three input vectors: the query vector $Q$, the key vector $K$, and the value vector $V$. The attention scores are computed as the dot product of the query vector with the transpose of the key vector, scaled by the square root of the key vector's dimensionality $d_k$:

    $\text{Attention}(Q, K, V) = \text{softmax}\left(\frac{QK^{\top}}{\sqrt{d_k}}\right)V$

The softmax function is then applied to the attention scores to obtain a probability distribution over the input sequence, which is then used to weigh the corresponding values. This allows the model to focus on different parts of the input sequence when generating each part of the output sequence.

 Multiheaded attention

The multiheaded attention is an extension of the attention head that allows the model to attend to different parts of the input sequence using multiple attention heads simultaneously. It is based on the idea of multihead attention introduced in the original transformer paper by Vaswani et al. in 2017.

The multiheaded attention takes three input vectors: the query vector $Q$, the key vector $K$, and the value vector $V$. The input vectors are first transformed into multiple sets of query, key, and value vectors using multiple weight matrices, one for each attention head. Specifically, let $h$ denote the number of attention heads, and $d_h$ denote the dimensionality of each attention head. Then, the input vectors are transformed into $h$ sets of query, key, and value vectors as follows:

    $Q_i = W_Q^i X, K_i = W_K^i X, V_i = W_V^i X, i = 1, ..., h$

where $W_Q^i$, $W_K^i$, and $W_V^i$ are the weight matrices for the $i$-th attention head, and $X$ is the input sequence.

For each attention head $i$, the attention scores are computed as the dot product of the query vector $Q_i$ with the transpose of the key vector $K_i$, scaled by the square root of the key vector's dimensionality $d_k$:

    $\text{Attention}_i(Q_i, K_i, V_i) = \text{softmax}\left(\frac{Q_iK_i^{\top}}{\sqrt{d_k}}\right)V_i$

The outputs of the attention heads are then concatenated along the feature dimension and transformed using another weight matrix to produce the final output of the multiheaded attention:

    $\text{MultiHead}(Q, K, V) = \text{Concat}(Attention_1(Q_1, K_1, V_1), ..., Attention_h(Q_h, K_h, V_h)) W^O$

where $\text{Concat}$ denotes the concatenation operation along the feature dimension, and $W^O$ is the output transformation weight matrix.

The multiheaded attention allows the model to attend to different parts of the input sequence using multiple attention heads simultaneously. Each attention head learns to attend to different parts of the input sequence, and the outputs of the attention heads are combined using a linear transformation to produce the final output. This allows the model to capture different aspects of the input sequence simultaneously, improving its ability to handle complex relationships between input and output sequences.

 Masked attention

The masked attention is a variant of the attention mechanism that is used in the decoder of the transformer architecture to prevent the model from attending to future tokens during decoding. It is based on the idea of causal masking introduced in the original transformer paper by Vaswani et al. in 2017.

The masked attention takes three input vectors: the query vector $Q$, the key vector $K$, and the value vector $V$. The attention scores are computed as the dot product of the query vector with the transpose of the key vector, scaled by the square root of the key vector's dimensionality $d_k$:

    $\text{Attention}(Q, K, V) = \text{softmax}\left(\frac{QK^{\top}}{\sqrt{d_k}}\right)V$

However, to prevent the model from attending to future tokens during decoding, a mask matrix $M$ is applied to the attention scores before the softmax function is applied. The mask matrix is a lower triangular matrix with zeros on the diagonal, indicating that the model should not attend to future tokens:

    $M = \begin{pmatrix}
    1 & 0 & 0 & \cdots & 0\\
    1 & 1 & 0 & \cdots & 0\\
    1 & 1 & 1 & \cdots & 0\\
    \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots\\
    1 & 1 & 1 & \cdots & 1
    \end{pmatrix}$

The masked attention scores are obtained by element-wise multiplication of the attention scores and the mask matrix:

    $\text{MaskedAttention}(Q, K, V) = \text{softmax}(MK^{\top})V$

The masked attention mechanism is a powerful tool for preventing the model from attending to future tokens during decoding. By applying a mask matrix to the attention scores, the model is forced to attend only to the tokens that have already been generated, ensuring that the output sequence is generated in a causal manner.

 Encoder

The encoder is the first half of the transformer architecture that processes the input sequence and produces a contextualized representation of the input tokens. It consists of a stack of $N$ identical layers, each of which contains two sub-layers: a multi-headed self-attention layer and a position-wise fully connected feed-forward network.

The multi-headed self-attention layer allows the model to attend to different parts of the input sequence and capture complex relationships between the input tokens. The attention scores are computed using the query, key, and value vectors, which are derived from the input tokens using three separate weight matrices. The output of the multi-headed self-attention layer is then passed through a linear transformation to produce the final output.

The position-wise fully connected feed-forward network allows the model to learn complex non-linear transformations of the input tokens. It consists of two fully connected layers with a ReLU activation function in between. The input to the feed-forward network is first transformed using a weight matrix and a bias vector, producing a new output. The output of the first linear transformation is then passed through the ReLU activation function and another linear transformation, using a weight matrix and a bias vector, to produce the final output of the feed-forward network.

The output of the position-wise fully connected feed-forward network is then added to the output of the multi-headed self-attention layer, and the result is normalized using layer normalization. This adds residual connections to the encoder, allowing the model to learn more complex transformations of the input sequence while preserving the original input.

By using multi-headed self-attention and position-wise fully connected feed-forward networks, the encoder is able to capture complex relationships between the input tokens and produce a rich contextualized representation of the input sequence.

 Adapted architectures

--- Decoder-only

Some transformer models, such as early GPT models, only use the decoder part of the architecture. These models do not have an encoder and instead rely on a large amount of self-supervised pretraining data to learn useful representations of text.

--- Encoder-only

Other transformer models, such as BERT, use only the encoder part of the architecture. These models are bidirectional, meaning they can process text in both directions, and are trained on a variety of NLP tasks.

--- Both

Most modern transformer models, such as GPT-3 and T5, use both the encoder and decoder parts of the architecture. These models can process text in both directions and are trained on a wide range of NLP tasks.

The full transformer architecture consists of an encoder and a decoder, both of which use the self-attention and feed-forward network components described above. The encoder and decoder are connected via an attention mechanism that allows the decoder to attend to different parts of the encoder's output when generating each part of the output sequence. This allows the model to capture complex relationships between the input and output sequences and generate a coherent output sequence.

The full transformer architecture is a powerful tool for natural language processing tasks such as machine translation, text summarization, and question answering.  Pseudocode

The following pseudocode shows the encoder-decoder mechanism of the transformer architecture:

    function transformer(x, y):
        x_mask = create_mask(x)
        y_mask = create_look_ahead_mask(y)
        
        encoder_output = encoder(x, x_mask)
        decoder_output = decoder(y, encoder_output, y_mask)
        
        return decoder_output

    function encoder(x, x_mask):
        for _ in range(num_layers):
            with reuse(scope):
                multi_headed_attention_output = multi_headed_self_attention(x, x, x, x_mask)
                x = layer_norm(multi_headed_attention_output + x)
                
                feed_forward_output = feed_forward(x)
                x = layer_norm(feed_forward_output + x)
        
        return x

    function decoder(y, encoder_output, y_mask):
        for _ in range(num_layers):
            with reuse(scope):
                masked_multi_headed_attention_output = masked_multi_headed_self_attention(y, y, y, y_mask)
                y = layer_norm(masked_multi_headed_attention_output + y)
                
                multi_headed_attention_output = multi_headed_attention(y, encoder_output, encoder_output, y_mask)
                y = layer_norm(multi_headed_attention_output + y)
                
                feed_forward_output = feed_forward(y)
                y = layer_norm(feed_forward_output + y)
        
        return y

This pseudocode assumes that the encoder and decoder each consist of a variable number of layers, and that the multi-headed self-attention and multi-headed attention sublayers are implemented using the attention mechanism described above. The create_mask and create_look_ahead_mask functions are used to create the appropriate masks for the encoder and decoder, and the layer_norm function is used to apply layer normalization to the outputs of each sublayer.

 Terminology

--- Variants

* Encoder-Only Transformers: Used in models like BERT, where the transformer is used only for encoding the input sequence.
* Decoder-Only Transformers: Used in models like GPT, where the transformer is used only for generating the output sequence.
* Encoder-Decoder Transformers: Used in models like T5, where the transformer is used for both encoding the input sequence and decoding the output sequence.

* Text Embedding and Representation Learning: Used in models like BERT, where the transformer is used to learn rich contextualized representations of text.
* Machine Translation: Used in models like NMT, where the transformer is used to translate text from one language to another.

 RoPE

The Rotary Positional Embedding (RoPE) is a technique for positional encoding in transformer architectures that uses rotary embeddings to encode the position of each token in the input sequence.

Mathematically, RoPE encodes the position of a token at index $i$ in the input sequence as a pair of sinusoidal functions:

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
        \text{RoPE}(x_i, pos) &= (x_i \cdot (\cos(pos / 10000^(2i/d_model)), x_i \cdot(\sin(pos / 10000^(2i/d_model))) ) 
    
        pos_i     &= 2\pi \cdot 10000^-(2 [j] / d_\text{model})
    \end{aligned}
    $$

where $x_i$ is the input token, $pos$ is the position of the token in the sequence, $d_\text{model}$ is the dimensionality of the input tokens, and $[j]$ refers to the $j$-th element of the input token.

During the attention computation, the rotary embeddings are applied to the query and key vectors using a rotary embedding matrix $R$:

    $
    [Q, K]_j = R_j · [Q, K]_j
    $

where $[Q, K]_j$ is the $j$-th element of the query or key vector, and $R_j$ is the $j$-th row of the rotary embedding matrix.

The advantage of RoPE over other positional encoding methods is that it allows the transformer to attend to relative positions in the input sequence, rather than absolute positions. This makes the model more invariant to the length of the input sequence and can improve performance on tasks with varying input lengths.

ALiBi

Attention with Linear Biases (ALiBi) is a positional encoding method for transformers that replaces the fixed sinusoidal positional embeddings with a simple linear bias term that increases linearly with the distance between tokens.

Mathematically, the ALiBi bias for the attention score between tokens $i$ and $j$ is computed as:

    $
    b_i, j = -|i - j|/K
    $

where $K$ is a learnable scalar parameter that controls the slope of the linear bias.

During the attention computation, the ALiBi bias is added to the attention scores:

    $
    S = QK^⊤ + ALiBiBias
    $

where $Q$ and $K$ are the query and key matrices, respectively, and $ALiBiBias$ is the ALiBi bias matrix.

The advantage of ALiBi over other positional encoding methods is that it is simpler and cheaper to compute than sinusoidal positional embeddings or rotary embeddings. It also avoids the potential issues with positional embeddings that arise from the periodicity of the sinusoidal functions.

Unlike RoPE, ALiBi does not learn relative positions, but it is cheaper to compute and can still improve the performance of the transformer on tasks with varying input lengths.

Relative Position Encodings

Relative position encodings are a method for encoding the relative position between tokens in a sequence, rather than their absolute positions. This allows the model to attend to relative positions in the input sequence, rather than absolute positions.

Mathematically, the relative position encoding for the attention score between tokens $i$ and $j$ is computed as:

    $
    b_i, j = W_r[p_i - p_j]
    $

where $p_i$ and $p_j$ are the absolute positions of tokens $i$ and $j$, respectively, and $W_r$ is a learnable matrix that maps the difference in positions to a bias term.

During the attention computation, the relative position encoding bias is added to the attention scores:

    $
    S = QK^⊤ + b_i, j
    $

where $Q$ and $K$ are the query and key matrices, respectively, and $b_i, j$ is the relative position encoding bias.

The advantage of relative position encodings over other positional encoding methods is that they allow the transformer to attend to relative positions in the input sequence, rather than absolute positions. This makes the model more invariant to the length of the input sequence and can improve performance on tasks with varying input lengths.

Unlike RoPE, ALiBi, and sinusoidal positional embeddings, relative position encodings do not assume any particular form for the positional encoding, and can therefore capture more complex relationships between positions in the sequence.

KV caching is a technique for efficient decoding of autoregressive transformers that stores the key-value pairs of previously generated tokens, so that they can be reused in subsequent decoding steps.

Speculative decoding is a technique for accelerating the decoding of autoregressive transformers by decoding multiple tokens in parallel using a technique called speculative decoding.

The basic idea of speculative decoding is to decode multiple tokens in parallel by generating multiple possible continuations of the input sequence and selecting the most likely continuation based on a scoring function.

The scoring function can be based on the log probabilities of the generated tokens or on a more sophisticated metric, such as a language model score.

The generated continuations can be stored in a cache and used as input for the next decoding step, allowing the model to generate multiple tokens in parallel.

The advantage of speculative decoding is that it can significantly reduce the decoding time of autoregressive transformers while maintaining high-quality outputs. This makes it particularly useful for applications such as language translation, text generation, and speech recognition.

The disadvantage of speculative decoding is that it requires additional memory to store the generated continuations and can be computationally expensive if too many tokens are decoded in parallel.

There are several ways to implement speculative decoding, including beam search, diversity-promoting decoding, and nucleus sampling.

 Beam search

Beam search is a decoding strategy that maintains a fixed number of candidate hypotheses at each decoding step. At each step, the top-k hypotheses are expanded, and the bottom-k hypotheses are pruned based on their likelihood scores.

The process is repeated until a stopping criterion is met, such as reaching a maximum length or generating an end-of-sequence token.

The advantage of beam search is that it can find high-quality hypotheses by exploring a larger portion of the hypothesis space than greedy decoding.

The disadvantage of beam search is that it can be computationally expensive and memory-intensive, especially for long sequences or large beams.

Diversity-promoting decoding

Diversity-promoting decoding is a decoding strategy that encourages the model to generate diverse outputs by penalizing hypotheses that are similar to each other.

One popular diversity-promoting decoding strategy is nucleus sampling, which selects a subset of hypotheses based on their cumulative likelihood probabilities and samples from this subset.

Another diversity-promoting decoding strategy is top-p sampling, which selects a subset of hypotheses based on their cumulative probabilities and samples from this subset.

The advantage of diversity-promoting decoding is that it can generate diverse outputs that are useful for applications such as text generation and creative writing.

The disadvantage of diversity-promoting decoding is that it can be less efficient than other decoding strategies, such as greedy decoding or beam search, and may require additional tuning to achieve good results.

Nucleus sampling

Nucleus sampling is a decoding strategy that selects a subset of hypotheses based on their cumulative likelihood probabilities and samples from this subset.

The subset of hypotheses is defined as the smallest set of hypotheses whose cumulative likelihood probabilities exceed a threshold value, known as the "nucleus."

The advantage of nucleus sampling is that it can generate diverse outputs while maintaining a controlled level of diversity.

The disadvantage of nucleus sampling is that it can be less efficient than other decoding strategies, such as greedy decoding or beam search, and may require additional tuning to achieve good results.

 Sub-quadratic transformers

Sub-quadratic transformers are transformer architectures that achieve sub-quadratic complexity in the sequence length, allowing them to handle long sequences more efficiently.

The most common approach to achieve sub-quadratic complexity is to use attention mechanisms that operate on smaller subsets of tokens, such as the sliding-window attention mechanism or the sparse attention mechanism.

Sliding-window attention operates on a fixed-size window of tokens around the current position, reducing the complexity from quadratic to linear in the sequence length.

Sparse attention operates on a sparsely sampled subset of tokens, reducing the complexity from quadratic to sub-quadratic in the sequence length.

The advantage of sub-quadratic transformers is that they can handle long sequences more efficiently, making them useful for applications such as long-form text generation and speech recognition.

The disadvantage of sub-quadratic transformers is that they may sacrifice some accuracy compared to standard transformers, and may require additional tuning to achieve good results.

 Random Feature Attention

Random Feature Attention (RFA) is a simplified version of the attention mechanism that uses random projections to approximate the attention scores.

Mathematically, RFA computes the attention scores as follows:

    $
    S_i, j = x_i^⊤·Rx_j
    $

where $x_i$ and $x_j$ are the input tokens, $R$ is a random projection matrix, and $·$ denotes the Hadamard product.

During the attention computation, the RFA scores are normalized using softmax:

    $
    A_i, j = \text{softmax}(S_i, j / √(d))
    $

where $d$ is the dimensionality of the input tokens, and $\text{softmax}$ is the softmax function.

The advantage of RFA over the standard attention mechanism is that it is cheaper to compute, as it avoids the need to compute the dot product of all pairs of input tokens. Instead, it uses a random projection matrix to project the input tokens onto a lower-dimensional space, where the dot product can be computed more efficiently.

The disadvantage of RFA is that it may not capture all the pairwise interactions between the input tokens, as it relies on random projections to approximate the attention scores. This may limit its ability to capture complex relationships between the input tokens.

Unlike the standard attention mechanism, RFA does not use learnable parameters to compute the attention scores, making it a simpler and more lightweight alternative. However, this also means that RFA may not be able to learn as complex or nuanced relationships between the input tokens as the standard attention mechanism.

One way to extend the transformer to handle multiple modalities is to use a shared embedding space, where the input tokens from different modalities are mapped to a common latent space using a shared set of parameters.

For example, in the case of image-text matching, the image features can be extracted using a convolutional neural network (CNN) and the text features can be extracted using a transformer-based language model, and both sets of features can be mapped to a common embedding space using a shared set of parameters.

Another way to extend the transformer to handle multiple modalities is to use a modular architecture, where each modality is processed by a separate module, and the outputs of the modules are combined using a fusion module.

For example, in the case of image-text matching, the image features can be extracted using a CNN and the text features can be extracted using a transformer-based language model, and both sets of features can be processed by separate transformer-based modules, and the outputs of the modules can be combined using a fusion module.

The disadvantage of using a shared embedding space is that it may require more training data to learn the shared representation, and the model may be sensitive to differences in the feature distributions of the different modalities.
